generated_json.title: History of Present Illness
content: Patient reports progressive bilateral hip pain due to severe degenerative joint disease (DJD), with bone-on-bone changes noted on imaging. Symptoms have persisted for years, with worsening pain impacting mobility. Previous cortisone injections provided temporary relief lasting approximately one month. Patient is scheduled for a nerve block test next Wednesday to assess efficacy before potential ablation. Patient is overweight (current weight 300 lbs, BMI 44), with a history of lipedema, prior DVT/PE, and atrial fibrillation. Patient expresses interest in hip replacement surgery but is concerned about risks and timing, particularly regarding retirement and insurance coverage. Weight loss is a key focus to reduce surgical risk. Patient is motivated to proceed with treatment but seeks relief in the short term via nerve block while working toward weight reduction.
generated_json.instruction:
Provide a detailed summary of the patient's current illness based on their report. Include a thorough description of symptoms, noting their onset, duration, and severity or intensity. Discuss any changes or developments in symptoms since their onset and identify factors that may exacerbate or relate to these symptoms, such as specific activities, foods, or medications. Document any prior treatments or remedies the patient has attempted, noting their efficacy. Describe how these symptoms impact the patient's daily activities, overall well-being, and quality of life. Capture information about any individuals mentioned by the patient, specifying their relationship and any pertinent interactions or conversations related to the illness.

sub-section.title: Plan
content: Proceed with nerve block test next Wednesday to assess efficacy.
If test is positive, proceed with nerve ablation for short-term pain relief.
Initiate weight loss program with goal of reducing weight to 260â270 lbs to decrease surgical risk.
Continue Eliquis as prescribed; discontinue 3 days prior to surgery and restart postoperatively.
Educate patient on hip replacement surgery, including risks, benefits, recovery timeline, and implant details (Smith & Nephew Anthology & Art, metal-ceramic composite).
Provide patient with surgical brochure and detailed information on recovery, including home therapy and post-op follow-up schedule.
Reassess in two months to evaluate weight loss progress, pain control, and readiness for surgical planning.
